review_title: Avoid What the Critics Say. Enjoy "Son of the Mask"!
review_detailed_main:
Sadly, this film is not doing well at the box office, but it should have. This is a frantic and funny follow up to "The Mask", and I enjoyed it. As he has proved with 2001's "Cats & Dogs", director Lawrence Guterman knows how to make a live-action cartoon. He uses weird, yet inventive, camera angles that adds more laughs to the film.

The film is also jam-packed with brilliant special effects that excel from the effects of the first film. Although the film isn't better than "The Mask", it's pretty close, and it's even wackier than its predecessor.

"Son of the Mask" is also being trashed by the film critics who probably doesn't have the knowledge to know that this is a KID'S FILM. It really does get annoying when critics always lambastes family films. My advice is to avoid their opinions and go see the movie. You might be glad you did.

review_title: Why do movies like this get funded???? Jesus
review_detailed_main: It's probably the worst movie I've ever seen so far, it's good that almost no one remembers this happened because it's a immeasurable disaster (of course I remember it and it's not a really pleasant sensation. I mean, c'mon Hollywood, why do you gotta make a remake or sequel of every damn movie? You are just wasting money and ruining classics (because The Mask is a classic comedy of the 90s and one of Jim Carrey's finest works). Such a shame that Alan Cumming, late Bob Hoskins and any actor of this ensemble decided to sign for this. Anyway, this is a forgettable movie and the world stills going it's way even though this disaster was made.

A film lacking in emotion, with a bad script, sometimes even becoming a nightmare, where humour is conspicuous by its absence and where situations are forced to try and get a laugh out of us.

Another film, of the many that have been released recently, is of a commercial nature, because with so many sequels, second and third parts, they seek more revenue than trying to make quality films.

For this film, I only highlight one thing and that is that I gave the Oscar to the "dog", which for me is the best part of the film and he plays his role with total ease and without making mistakes. You can imagine how the other actors do it.

This movie is so bad that made me create an account to warn people about it.

Good thing first: If this movie was good would create a great memorabilia. A lot of itens made for the movie were beautiful, like itens, clothes etc. They had really good people working in that, enough to not rate it 0/10 even if I could. It reminds me Batman & Robin in that way.

Besides that, man, what a terrible movie... How did people spend more than 80 million in this?!?!? Simply unbelievable.

Too many closes, bad filming, random editing, no sense of continuity, zero charisma, negative fun, silly dialogue, embarassing jokes, and the list goes on and on. The Mask with that orange hair and no expressions? And a baby with superpowers? C'mon...

The movie is so bad that can't even be cult, because who made this really thought it would be awesome.

Look, I already knew it would be bad. Jamie Kennedy was always dull, and I saw his picture as the Mask before. But it still shocked me. Yeah... that bad. You just don't need this in your life.

Son of the Mask is a comedy film directed by Lawrence Guterman. The film stars Jamie Kennedy, Alan Cumming, Traylor Howard, Kal Penn, Steven Wright, Late Bob Hoskins and Ryan and Liam Falconer as Tim's baby Alvey.

The film was a stand alone remake of the 1994 film.

A cartoonist faces a dilemma when his dog chances upon the mask of Loki. After conceiving an infant son by the magical powers of the mask, he understands just how difficult child raising can be.

There are certain films which leaves so great impression on the viewers that remaking the film or making the sequel of the film is always a tedious task and one needs some great story or some great creativity to either recreate or make sequel but alas in the case of this film we neither has any great story or great creativity and has some terrible plot and messy execution.

The plot of the film is stale and cliched and the execution is terrible, the film should've never been made in the first place. The film lacks almost everything. The film has some bad VFX, pathetic acting, humorless jokes and pale climax.

I didn't found any reason to advise you to watch this film for me it was a complete waste of time.

review_title: It's not even one star!! It's a quarter of a star
review_detailed_main: Awful!! I regret seeing that movie. It lacked everything the mask had. It wasn't funny at all. Jamie Kennedy can't act!! The baby was annoying!! It would've been a whole hell of a lot better if Jim Carrey reprised his role and made it a different story.

review_title: No one's sure what they're doing!
review_detailed_main:
For a 2005 movie, the animation's pretty good at places and there's a part of history they want you to know. Across the movie, cloggy mind of the film makers or a very different audience as targets, they fail to deliver the context or the content required to please the Critics.

This was all that was there in the movie, The Mask was quite a popular TV Animation Series in many areas of the world but they messed it all up. The good thing is that it has got some catchy actups that can attract the children and especially babies as you well know they love colours and gestures which they take as actions.

The movie has the relations of a newly made father and son compared to another father-son pair that's messed up and the Family of the Mask, the Dog, Loki, ( and Thor) and the Gods are creamed up in between.

Better make sure that one has the movie's playing time as completely useless to invest the time to watch this. No pun intended.

I would love to be able to come on to this site and say that I've found something good about 'Son of the Mask' that as it stands 284 other reviewers have not.

I can't though.

This is dire. A family friendly rehash of 'The Mask' that reeks of desperation and a film studio with a franchise burning a hole in its pocket and determined to use it no matter how bad the quality is.

Alan Cumming was rubbish once upon a time in a Flintstones film, but double, no treble how bad he was there and you've got his performance in this film.

It's a real shame, because this had potential, but it's charmless and lacking in any real sense of comedy.

The main actor and actress were clearly just bargain bin versions of Jim Carrey and Cameron Diaz. The portrayal of the original Mask could only be performed by someone with the physical comedy chops of Carrey - the voice, impressions, physical comedy and most importantly facial movements.

The animation honestly could have been worse, but still was horrifying at times. In theory the plot could have worked well, but the limits of and over-reliance on CGI made it hard to connect to anything going on.

I gave an extra point for the creators wringing every last drop out of the dog actor they used for the movie. That thing does a million different tricks.

review_title: A movie that parents can watch with the kids
review_detailed_main: FAMILY MOVIE. Please read my entire comment: Yes, this isn't serious theater, which is fairly obvious given it's overall low rating. But it's something fun to watch with the kids. It's actually very well acted (Alan Cumming, less so Jamie Kennedy), the effects are fairly cool, and overall, the plot and gags are fun. The special effects are awesome. Mom and dad both can watch this along with the little and big kids. Everyone will be entertained. A few drinks won't hurt (mom and dad only, please). Even the dog will like it, especially given the doggie sound effects and doggie funnies. The movie is definitely worth a watch. It is lighthearted and doesn't take itself too seriously, unlike many of the people who voted on this film.

review_title: It depends on what you expect

review_detailed_main:
Normally when judging movies, it is useful to consider the context of what it is trying to be. Now unless "Son of the Mask" was TRYING to be a saccharine CG-fetishizing suck fest, it probably missed its mark.

Jamie Kennedy is truly an underrated creative talent whom I hoped would carry the movie. Add in Ben Stein, Bob Hoskins, Kal Penn, and a refreshing supporting role by Steven Wright and you can see how much screen time was wasted on drawn-out cartoonish action sequences and digital manipulations of the baby's three expressions.

Taking into account the director's previous work on "Cats and Dogs" and "Antz," it is easy to see the source of the neglect: human characters (and actors) seem to take a back seat to novelty leads under Guterman's direction.

Several segments were entirely over-descriptive of the plot/upcoming action to even be considered subtle foreshadowing, including a gratuitous 2-minute synopsis of a classic cartoon. Rather than innovative media sampling and dynamic background asides, certain parts just come off as cinematic laziness.

There's nothing wrong with a little toilet humor, especially in a kid's movie; however some of the bodily fluid scenes would probably be considered profane by the FCC.

The special effects were pretty seamless and elaborated on the conventions established by the first film, but for the most part served as lengthy breaks from plot advancement and character development. They certainly got the right FX house, because ILM has plenty of experience in this field! Alan Cummings played a dynamic and likable villain, and Traylor Howard a generic, but hot, Gen-Xer mom.

Overall, the movie had its moments, but missed the boat by ignoring a talented and capable cast and dumbing down the humor to the point of being patronizing even to children. The best kids movies work on several levels.

I'd recommend sitting this one out and giving the rug rats something to do for 86 minutes.

review_title: Theatrical release is nothing more than promo for video release
review_detailed_main:
The only reason this movie gets a 1 from me is that you have to give it something.

The movie, no matter what the fans of this mess want to say, is nothing more than straight to video fair that was thrown to paying audiences to basically promote it for the video release. It is an insult to any one that wastes their time and money on this train wreck of a movie.

How bad is it? The movie in a matter of 3 short weeks has totally fallen out of the top 20 and is down to one showing in the basement room of most theaters. The only reason this movie has made over 10 million is due to the inflated ticket prices of today.

The movie is scheduled for a May 17th release. That is right, only 3 months from its theatrical release it will appear on video shelves. Further evidence that New Line is trying to save what money they can. With the budget for this movie close to 90 million and another 20 million promotion, it is this years Gigli. a failure on all levels. All I have to say is good thing New Line made tons of money off the LOtR movies. Unfortunately this crap has taken a large chunk of money out of the LOtR cash kitty New Line had saved up.

Shame on New Line for ripping people off of hard earned money and time.

review_title: I loved it Almost More than my Kids

review_detailed_main:
About as good as knocking one out with sand paper.

Peppa pig is more exciting than this sugar honey ice tea!

review_title: The apple has fallen VERY far from the tree...
review_detailed_main:
Despite the feelings of some; I felt that a follow-up to "The Mask" had some potential mileage even without Carrey, because at least in story terms it's less about the individual as their regular selves than how they're transformed by getting their mitts on the magical artifact.

The most immediate problem that presents itself as things get underway though is that, aside from the decent-enough pre-credits sequence in the museum; this movie takes forever to put together what should have been a fairly simple plot. The star of the show should have been the Mask effects here, since this time you don't have an actor half as skilled as Jim Carrey at making you invest your emotions in the main character. You can tell the producers are itching to get 'wacky' and put their money up on screen too, but before they can do that they disappointingly decided that what was necessary first was to write lame domesticated scenes in an attempt to bullishly hammer home a sickly sappy wholesome moral. I didn't care about Kennedy or Howard; nor did I want to watch their dog monopolise the Mask for what felt like an eternity, turning a mildly amusing 'bit' from the first film into an entire and crushingly leaden subplot for the second...

Once Loki got on the trail of the baby, it improved just enough for me to think it bearable. I liked the idea of a folklore-d foot-soldier taking charge of an innocent baby (it put me in mind of the immeasurably superior "Labyrinth", whether intentionally or not) and the movie references were fun at first, I guess ("Ransom", for example). Overall, though, it's difficult to deny that this is a poorly-conceived sequel that wastes its opportunities by stalling for far too long and never knowing what best to do with the powers of the Mask when the time is felt ultimately right.

review_title: If something isn't broken, don't try and fix it !!
review_detailed_main:
OMG !!!!!!!. I am embarrassed to say that I have just sat through the entire movie. I suppose you can't give a proper review if you don't. It is very easily the worst film I have ever seen.

I watched the premier of the original Mask in '93 and was completely blown away. I went back a couple of days later to see it again because I enjoyed it so much.

A classic is best left alone without a sequel. For me it was not even worthy of calling a sequel. The screenplay was crap, the acting was crap, the so-called special effects were a ridiculous attempt to recreate some of the funnier scenes of the original but completely failed on all levels.

Ed Wood was probably the worst director of all time, and his film " Plan 9 from Outer Space " is reputed to be the worst film of all time. I love it!! It really IS so crap that it is funny because of that fact. Son of the Mask on the other hand is like taking a classic such as The Green Mile or Shawshank Redemption and making a 3rd rate cartoon out of them voiced by actors with completely no substance.

A franchise CAN consist of only one film and this is a perfect example.

How Bob Hoskins and one of my favourite comedians Steven Wright got mixed up in this pile of trash is one of the great mysteries of the universe.

AVOID AT ALL COSTS !!!

review_title: If the goal of this movie was to...
review_detailed_main:
make someone more dumb, then the director succeeded. If the purpose was to entertain and be cute, it failed miserably. This has to be one of the worst movies ever made. The plot was beyond horrible. This was so silly and stupid; I find it hard to believe a 10 year old would like this. Loki, god of mischief, comes to earth looking for his mask. A dog happens upon the mask and brings it home to its owner. Both the dog and owner use the mask, and the owner, Tim, even has a mask baby. The whole ending with all the silliness of the baby and car chase and everything was horrible. I think this movie would make anyone over the age of 10 stupider.

FINAL VERDICT: If you value your brain cells, stay away from this.

I took my niece to see this yesterday. My brother now owes me larger than he ever has before. Not only this the movie follow no rational chain of thought or logical progression, not only did no character behave according to the rules we thought the movie had provided, not only is there no connection to the original Mask, save in name alone, but the kid actually cried through half of it. Not bawled, that would have been sweet reprieve, and I'd have had to leave, just cried, usually because she thought the doggie was going to be evil again. She didn't understand, and neither did I. I gave this movie a 2/10, but only because I'm reserving my 1/10 for something worse to come along. I was able to think of things that would have made it worse, and I liked Alan Cumming's hair.

review_title: I Will Never Take The Ratings On This Site Seriously Again!
review_detailed_main: I just watched this on DVD with my 35 yr. old son and 5 yr. old granddaughter and we all laughed from beginning to end. This is probably the funniest movie I have ever seen in my 55 years!I never had any desire to see this movie before because of the way it was trashed here.I'm so glad that I decided to check it out when I saw it at my library. It is soo much better than the first,and we enjoyed that one as well.To be put in the WORST Movie category on this site is incomprehensible!As far as I'm concerned IMDb might as well do away with the ratings here,because this is just one of many,many times the crazy,undeserved(overrated and underrated) ratings here have stunned me.If you like hilarious comedy, ignore the lousy ratings given here and check it out. I don't believe anyone with even a smidgen of a sense of humor could be disappointed.

I got to see this last Saturday thanks to my sister scoring some premiere passes.

And I have to admit, from what I had seen before-hand I wasn't looking forward to it. I really only went cause it was the premiere, free, and I took my cousin who really wanted to see it.

That said, I was pleasantly surprised at how it turned out. It was well above what I had expected. It's definitely a family movie aimed at the younger crowd but it was fairly entertaining most of the way through.

Jamie Kennedy is no Jim Carrey as the Mask but these scenes are few and he's good otherwise. The baby is cute, the dog, disturbing, but it's Alan Cumming's Loki who really steals the show. The movie is worth seeing for him alone.

Without giving anything away, the movie has it's share of laughs, flows well enough, and is definitely intended as a family movie.

So there you have my early review.

My 9 yr old cousin put it his way; "If I had as many arms as an octopus, I'd have all eight thumbs up. ... But I liked the first one better."

review_title: P.U. -- but good for non-discriminating 7 year olds.
review_detailed_main:
This "film," and I use that term loosely, reminds me of the first joke my daughter wrote, at eighteen months: "P.U., stinky poopies!"

Like that joke, this movie can only appeal to the very young, the very immature, or the very stupid.

That said, there are a few bright spots.

The effects, where the majority of the reputed $100 million went, are kinetic and convincing -- I mean, as convincing as those kind of kinetic CGI effects can be. The CGI baby effects are not great, but I imagine those are very hard to do well... although for a hundred-million bucks, they could have been better!

Moose, the dog from "Frasier," phoned in his usual exemplary performance. Steven Wright did well with a small part. Alan Cummings was, well, Alan Cummings-as-villain, which we've seen before, and Bob Hoskins as Odin was unrecognizable, but enjoyable.

The actress playing Mrs. Avery was cute-as-a-button, as you'd expect, and Jamie Kennedy stunk, as you'd expect. His best role so far was in the Scream trilogy (not to be confused with the Lord of the Rings trilogy), and in Three Kings. He should stick, perhaps, to more subtle forms of comedy. Jim Carrey, he ain't.

The writing and direction were, if anything, worse than Kennedy's performance. I semi-remember one clever (though seven-year-old clever) line that I wish someone would quote accurately for the "Memorable Quotes" section. Something about Avery's proposed costume being the "crappiest crap in Craptown," it was a second-grade joke, but sort of funny in context.

Over all, since there's nothing lower than a "one," I give this film a "one."

review_title: This is why Jim Carrey doesn't do sequels
review_detailed_main:
Jim Carrey was a big influence on both me and my brother and "The Mask" was one of his best comedies. The ending set up a sequel that many thought would never be made. This film has the honor of being the first movie that I knew would be horrible right from the trailer. I remember when this film was promoted and how insane it was anyone would want to have their name associated with it. We end Channel Awesome Month with one of the worst films ever reviewed by the Nostalgia Critic. This movie features Loki searching for his mask that a guy named Tim and his dog find and use.

He has sex with his wife (a family picture!) and has a son that inherits all the powers of the mask. I had seen the Critic's review so many times (if only because it was the first one that referenced "My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic") that I was familiar with most of the material. There's still stupid scenes he didn't really talk about. Loki tries to search for his mask through various disguises including a plumber with his butt crack. Why exactly wasn't Loki searching for the mask in the first movie? If Odin knew there was a baby born from the mask, how did he not know where he was?

The only actor or character from the first movie to appear is Ben Stein. I would honestly watch his stupid anti-evolution documentary over this. The special effects are some of the worst I've ever seen with the baby looking hideous in most shots. Loki only appeared briefly in "Avengers: Infinity War", but that was still a much better representation of him. As we end Channel Awesome Month, we start next with Sequel Month! If Doug and Rob Walker refuse to address the controversy surrounding their website, than that's their problem. 1/2*

review_title: that movie was a little stupid but fun and cute
review_detailed_main: Bob Hoskins as Odin was very interesting so does Ben Stein as Dr. Neuman. Jammie Kennedy as Tim Avery was a little stupid. Alvey the baby was very cute. Alan Cummings as Loki was cool. That was cool who they did it with a computer to make the baby use it's hand to hit Loki. Traylor Howard as Tonya Avery was beautiful. Kal Penn as Jorge was boring. Magda Szubanski as a Betty was very nice. Otis the dog is very interesting also. This story is about a mask that Odin tells Loki to find the mask. Otis found the mask in the river then went back to the Avery house. There are more you might like but a little stupid but fun and cute.

I don't know why this movie is in the bottom 100 I thought it was enjoyable! Obviously its not amazing to go into the top 250 but it still had a plot to it.

Everyone knows that the first one was much better mainly because of more experienced actors. In this on Jamie Kennedy did a great job at pulling off a hard working father. Alan Cumming has worked in children's movies before such as Spy Kids but he was too very good.This movie may be a little silly with all the curses and stuff but this movie is a comedy it has to not make sense its just a bit of fun! I know loads of people hate this movie but to be honest there are much worse movies than this. In my opinion this was a fun movie and I would advice to watch it you are feeling like watching a fun film.

The sequel to "The Mask" is out! But this one doesn't have Jim Carrey. What a pity! I think this sequel should be a story of its own. Jamie Kennedy best known for his own show, and the comedy "Malibu's Most Wanted" tries his luck as the green masked buffoon that made Carrey famous. The real deal was the dog who wears the mask more than Tim Avery(Kennedy). And this dog is more mischievous than Milo. He'll do anything for attention. As for Tim, he is so preoccupied, he lets everything whizzes by him. Including that Norse god Loki(Alan Cumming). One question comes to mind, "Where is Thor?" That would be another show.

This movie is good, but it lacks the hit making chemistry that "The Mask" has. Though it has Ben Stein from the first one, It was funny from the robbery scene where Loki dealt with the security guards when he said "Thanks for dropping by". A real knee slapper there! Some parts really funny, some way too off the wall for me. This sequel was a few years too late. Rating 2.5 out of 5 stars.

review_title: Haven't seen it, but here's the deal...
Not related to The Mask at all
A cartoon with no plot, just animated effects.
review_detailed_main:
I usually try to review movies on their own merit but with this one, I have to go into some back story. The first Mask movie was not really a good movie, but it was watchable, mind you, I never really liked the Mask cartoon so my view might be a bit skewed. See, the first film had two things that this one did not. First, it had Jim Carrey in the lead role, who is able to act out in a way similar to the mask character, which gives the character a certain amount of verisimilitude. Secondly, it has a plot, there is a clear progression forwards where there are actual stakes for the characters. Also, the setting is a lot darker than in Son of the Mask which makes the character stand out more against the background.

Son of the Mask however, has no plot, there is stuff going on but the story doesn't move forward. The setting is this garish, cartoonish world where none of the masks shenanigans has any consequence. It really is just a cartoon with one over the top gag after another. The original had very little potential for a sequel, and yet they still tried to make a follow up by pouring a bucket load of animated effects on a weak script. It didn't work, the only reason I didn't give it a 1 was because it didn't make me all that angry.

review_title: No one's gonna give this movie credit...but it rocks!!
review_detailed_main: Okay..I know loads of people are going to disagree with me..or think I'm crazy..but I really enjoyed this film! I remember loving the first one but that was so long ago I couldn't really remember the actual storyline when I was watching this so I wasn't comparing it to the original, just enjoying it as one of those fun, slightly mental movies that is just a laugh. I used to watch Jamie Kennedy's show JKX (an earlier version of "punk'd" but without the celebrities and much madder set-ups!) and I was a big fan. He's absolutely hilarious! Although...he does end up being out-shined by the insane special effects and the even more special baby. Just watch this movie with a big bunch of friends and enjoy it for what it is: a mad-cap adventure with a weak storyline that somehow has a sweet ending, that really will have you in stitches. Oh, and if you just happen to enjoy it, check out Malibu's Most Wanted, another Jamie Kennedy great, based on one of the most popular skits from JKX. Jamie Kennedy ROCKS!!

review_title: If you love special effects, you must see Son of the Mask
review_detailed_main: Tim (Jaime Kennedy) and Tonya are a young married couple with different aspirations, at present. Tonya would love to start a family but Tim wants to first make it big, as a cartoonist, for the animation company he works for. Get ready for a turn of events. The couple's darling dog brings home THE mask, the one Jim Carrey wore in the first film and Tim falls under its spell for an evening. Not only does he score big points at a company party for his cartoon ideas, he also scores when he gets home. Tonya is delighted when she becomes pregnant. However, when their son Alvey is born, he has mask-like powers from time to time. This is known only to Tim and the Norse God Thor and his son, Loki. Seems Thor wants the mask out of human hands and orders Loki to find it and the magical child. Let the games begin. This is not really horrible entertainment, as one may have heard or expect. The plot zips along nicely and the performers do their jobs well, especially Alan Cumming as Loki. The art direction and special effects are the true highlights, however. The film sports vibrant colors everywhere and the effects are truly amazing. Watch Loki change identities, each one adorable, or watch the baby swing his father, Tim, around when he feels like it. And much more, including a big ending at the car garage. If you liked the first film, you will miss Carrey, no doubt about it. But, give this one a chance. It qualifies definitely as entertainment rather than art, which is not always an unwelcome thing. Smiles will abound at any showing.

Liked The mask? Do yourself a favor then and skip this movie. If I had to choose between this movie or smacking myself in the head over and over with a baseball bat, I would choose the baseball bat because it hurts less than this movie does! The acting was good and the movie was funny but it was too cartoonish and lacked the subtlety of the first movie. Jim Carrey did a way better job and was able to actually make his part believable. Actor of the dad just blew it. I mean the dad character was dumb and immature in the first place and then they get this guy who couldn't make the part good if he had three hundred years. I mean the guy who played the god was better at his part than the actor who played the dad! You want good? Then go see a different movie, chances are it'll be funnier and just a tad less like a cartoon gone horribly wrong.

I saw this in theaters when I was 9 because I absolutely LOVED The Mask with Jim Carry. I know now Carry doesn't do sequels (except for Ace Ventura). So this movie not having Jim Carry automatically made it horrible. I was incredibly disappointed when I saw this disgrace to film history.

If you have not see his movie, simply just don't it's not at all worth it. The Mask was great and that's all you need to see. I don't know what else to say, but I have to keep typing because IMDb requires 10 lines on comments. All I have left to say is don't watch this movie

Avoid it like the plague.

This movie isn't worth going to the theaters to watch, i did and i didn't like it, the effects on the movie are really well done, and you get a laugh here and there, but the story is really bad, it seemed like they had run out of ideas, and what is that of loki and odin getting along? that totally destroys norse mythology, and i guess they forgot that loki's powers only worked during the NIGHT!! If you really MUST see this movie rent it when it comes out, don't go to the movies for this!

They could have done a lot more with this than they did, it felt like they just wanted to do a movie to show off cool animation and effects

I went into this movie not quite sure if it could live up to its predecessor: The Mask. When I left the cinema i had my answer...it did live up to the original and even improved on it.

The acting in this film is top notch along with the witty script and great lightning effects. Its a shame this didn't come out a couple of months earlier to compete for best film, best actor and best director in the Oscars.

But not to worry, maybe this is a good thing as it will make it more art-house and it will grow a cult following. I give this a 10 out of 10 on all levels and advise people to see it.

review_title: A Sequel That Even Jim Carrey Would Hate
review_detailed_main:
What can I say? I'm sure most of the reviews on IMDb about this movie are terrible, and I'd like to add my voice to that lot. They should make it a law to stop movie-makers from taking hit Jim Carrey movies and making sequels without Jim that suck.

After doing so many good movies in the 1980s, Bob Hoskins seems to have hit rock-bottom. His performance as Odin can't save this turkey. Ditto Jamie Kennedy (who seems to be doing a poor Jim Carrey imitation) and Alan Cumming (who isn't much of an actor in my opinion). The dog-wearing-the-mask bit was already done in the first film, and the dancing baby singing 1940s swing tunes is an idea that would have been laughed off by the makers of "Ally McBeal".

Did the makers of this movie actually think that a scene where a baby attacks his father with squirting urine would make people laugh? It didn't for me. It made me cringe. Oh, the horror!!! Please just rent the original and avoid this dreck.

for me to poop on! If I had it my way, my review would stop there, but IMDb requires a minimum of ten lines of text for all user comments. Since I have nothing else to really say about the movie, I made a list of things that I'd rather do than watch this crap again. 1. Take a bath with my Christmas lights. 2. Drink lemonade... after chewing on a razor. 3. Attempt to domesticate a badger. 4. Do "YMCA" on the karaoke machine at the local biker bar. 5. Hug a tree.............. a flesh eating grizzly tree. That being said, I can only hope and pray that the makers of this film have resigned and devoted their lives to rehabilitating all the unfortunate souls that were tainted by this filth.

review_title: Possibly the worst movie ever made
review_detailed_main:
"Son of the Mask" is a terrible excuse of a movie. I went to see this with my friend and I still wish we had seen "Because of Winn-Dixie" instead. I must say that it is partially my fault, as I agreed to go see it with him. Being a fan of the first "Mask" movie (Jim Carrey was hilarious) I had hoped it wasn't as bad as all of the critics said it was.

Ten minutes into the movie I knew it was headed for disaster. Disgusting and pointless attempts at being funny got little seven and eight year old children shrieking with laughter, but the rest of us were left staring at the screen in disbelief.

Finding the movie as repulsive and unfunny as I did is surprising to even me, as I loved "Scary Movie" and "Anchorman", two films which many people I know found crude and offensive. But the thing is, "Son of the Mask" is not funny unless you're under the age of ten.

The film features lots of CGI in it, but it cannot save this piece of rubbish. Whoever allowed this movie to make it to the big screen was probably thinking it had potential, considering the success of its original. Unfortunately, it has none of the laughs, fun, or excitement of the first, creating a mockery of the original movie. I recommend renting the original "Mask" to anyone who is thinking about seeing this one. 1 star out of 10 is generous to this awful mess.

Want it or not, The Mask, starring Jim Carrey was an amazing success. The story was not perfect, but we can't forget it was a comedy and the kind of film din't require anything extremely good. But it was a success. Jim Carrey, an excellent comedian, and revealed to be a great dancer too. The effects, the characters, the environment, everything was pretty good and made it a very good movie. Almost everybody associates Jim Carrey to the Mask ans vise-versa.

Son of the mask is a disaster... and awful disaster. Everybody knows that making a second movie after a great success is risky and almost every time, is not so good as the first one. In this case the "not so good" could be a compliment, as Son Of The Mask revealed to be the worst movie i ever seen. But why? So here it goes: 1º - The characters are bad. they're personality is horrible, complete loosers (not like Stanley Hipkiss, not even close.). 2º - The actors are the worst i have ever seen. Come on people... making a second mask movie without Jim Carrey ??? or without any actor with the same status as Jim?? I mean, professionals! These guys can'0t even act as ordinary people in they's day-to-day lives... When I saw this Jamie Kennedy as the mask.... Jesus.... i couldn't believe... it was SO INCREDIBLY BAD!!! The make up, the posture, the face, everything.... the guy doesn't even move any muscle in his face... I can't believe they destroyed The Mask this way... people, put this in your mind: there will never be any Mask like Jim Carrey. Or even close! 3º The story is incredibly bad... when people watch a movie, there is supposed to be a connection between the watcher and the movie. there has got to be something interesting, something funny, something that makes you see the movie until the end. And actually like the movie. You don't have any connection to this movie. You star to watch and you wonder when it is over, 'cause it's so bad, you want to stop watching it! 4º Don't have the skill, don't mess. This title completely destroyed the mask, the funny the mask was. After a decade, people still watch the original The Mask starring Jim Carrey, and they still laugh an enjoy the movie as if it was the first time it was seen. With this disgusting sequel i'm afraid The Mask looses it's beauty in comedy and it's magic.

So, my advice is: if you liked very much The Mask, don't you dare to watch this Son Of The Mask thing, 'cause you're gonna get disappointed and very sad about what they've done with the original title. If you loved The Mask, forget that Son Of The Mask has ever been made. But actually, my advice is: EVERYONE -> DON'T WATCH THIS, DON'T RENT IT, DON'T BUY IT. IT'S SSSSSOOOOOOOOOO BBBBAAAAAADDDDDD!!!!!

I even saw someone's review saying that this Son Of The Mask is a great movie for kids... please... children are not "stupid beings". Can't they have good content, on what they see, anymore ? But that also has another point... The Mask was not supposed to be ONLY for kids... The original Mask was a movie for everyone!! AND IT WAS GOOD. I'm not just complaining, i mean, Son Of The Mask is an interesting title, i actually lead me to watch it. but please.... why use these title in such an awful movie?? why not a GOOD sequel???

I'm sorry Lawrence Guterman, but you could have done MUCH better. I know it's a cheap movie to direct... but the result is the worst thing i've ever seen, and i'm not the only one.

And by the way, to all actors of this movie, specially to Jamie Kennedy: go to acting school, or go there again. learn something there and come back to the movie business. And learn, as well, what is true comedy. Learn with Jim.

And if any director is thinking about making another movie about The Mask... please.... choose experts, choose great actors, great comedians, great effects, great music, and great story. otherwise... don't mess anymore, don't destroy The Mask anymore.

Well... i have NO idea why this movie has gotten such a low rating. My kids (age 5 and 9) saw this film 3 times in 4 days - and so did i, its a great and very, VERY funny. Its a worthy follow-up to 1st one with Jim Carry.

Don't Miss this movie, especially if you have kids. I don't know what the age rating is on this one - but i would not show it to kids under the age of 5.

The special effects are state of the art - the acting is great - and the comedy is hilarious.

Hope the will make a follow-up soon

Hey all, I have a little question. It's about the song through-out the credits.

Okay, so like most of you I rented the movie in DVD format and forced myself through it. (Not exactly what I was expecting but nonetheless entertaining).

Too lazy to wait for the credits to end, I returned the DVD, thinking that later I'd simply do a bit of research on the Internet.

But I'm coming up with nothing.

Does anyone know the title/artist even a chunk of lyrics from the song that was playing through the credits? It would be greatly appreciated, thank-you. :)

review_title: First Movie That I Actually Hated

review_detailed_main:
In Edge City, Loki (Alan Cumming) is looking for his mask but finds only replicas. The real mask is washed away to far off Fringe City. Odin commands his son Loki to find the mask or else. Otis the dog retrieves the mask for the Avery family. Tim Avery (Jamie Kennedy) is happily married to Tonya (Traylor Howard) but in fear of raising a baby. He's a struggling cartoonist working as a grunt with best friend Jorge (Kal Penn) in Animagine run by animation genius Daniel Moss (Steven Wright). He decides to wear the mask for the company Halloween party. It's a crazy time and he impresses his boss. He also consummates with the mask on and the resulting baby Alvey seems to have special powers.

This is a truly disappointing sequel. While the original is fun, this one is ugly and tiresome. Jamie Kennedy has a dash of annoying in his DNA. He has no charm. He compensates with brash annoying wacky comedy. Personally I don't find him funny at all which fits this movie perfectly. The animation looks ugly. The general look is bad kids TV. It's a Road Runner cartoon without the fun. The fact that the original is so great only makes this an even bigger failure.

I didn't know what I wasn't getting myself into: usually, I am not too fond of sequels. And this one didn't disappoint me either. If you are looking for the same quality movie as the original The Mask with Jim Carrey, then skip this selection altogether. I am not saying that without Jim the movie is not the same... Actually, that's exactly what I am saying: no Jim = no hilarity, no falling off your chair funny, no uniqueness. However, if you decide to have a movie that knows its limitations (and the loss of its major attraction), then the sequel isn't half that bad. Writing could have been better (a lot of information is given for granted, so you have to fill in using your own brain), but overall the plot holds together. Acting is not bad, and Jamie Kennedy is trying his best. I think he tries to follow Jim, and sometimes he succeeds. The final conclusion: this movie is NOT as bad as it could have been.

review_title: Not as bad as the critics say,but still one of the dumbest movies I've ever seen
review_detailed_main:
For the first time I lay my eyes on the cover of this film,I could tell that it was going one of the pointless movies ever made.So I was right.For the first few minutes of the film I found myself asking "these questions:

"The first movie was good enough,why make a second?"

"Are personally trying to make people want to hate this movie?" AND...

Why did you add a stupid baby in it?"

Seriously.The acting was kinda lousy,the directing and story was completely worthless,the special effects were okay i admit,a little too comically done for my taste,but overall the whole film was sort of all over the place.I mean okay.It had it cute moments,but like I said.Why would some idiot make a dumb sequel out of a very loved movie?

review_title: The only reason I didn't put a star rating is because they didn't have -18 as a choice.
This Vile Movie Is So Dreadful It May Change Your Life
review_detailed_main:
Let me start by stating that I am a big fan of the original Mask with Jim Carrey. I watched this movie because I purchased it as part of a double feature DVD for $5. And I must say with all seriousness, that I was absolutely dumbfounded by what I saw. It was, unquestionably, the worst movie I have ever seen in my entire life! I literally watched the whole movie, because I refused to believe that I had completely wasted my time spent watching it. I was absolutely convinced that there had to be at least one somewhat funny part in the movie. However, I was dead wrong. Jamie Kennedy's attempts at comedy in that movie were so awkward and uncomforting that I literally cringed throughout the whole thing. I probably felt similar to how a child feels when they are about to be molested by a pedophile. Unfortunately for me (the viewer), however, I did not have free candy or a nice ride in a white van to brag about. My innocence was stolen that day.

After watching the movie, two thoughts have stuck in my head regarding the film.

First off, I did not know that Hollywood actually made movies this bad. It seems that there should be some standard that all movies are required to meet. This was so bad, it didn't even seem real.

Secondly, as the movie went on, I found myself developing a profound hatred for Jamie Kennedy. It's been about two years since I viewed it, and I still feel that he needs to have his ass kicked for the part he played in it. What he has done to the world of Arts of Humanities is comparable to 1st-Degree Manslaughter.

I urge you to not watch this movie unless you are dedicated to being a part of history--as you can then say that you have watched the worst movie of all time. However, if you do decide to watch it for the hell of it, you run the risk of becoming less of a person.

review_title: Instead of being a sequel, it's more of a horrible sequel with no Jim Carrey or any funny moment in sight.
review_detailed_main:
Back in the 90's, we were given a film called, "The Mask", it was a really funny movie with Jim Carrey and got some positive feedback.

In 2005, we were given the sequel, "Son of the Mask". All I have to say is this, "THIS IS ONE OF THE WORST FILMS EVER MADE!!".

Not only it's a terrible sequel, but it ended up being one of the worst films ever made. I can give you three reasons why: 1. It was unfunny. REALLY UNFUNNY.

2. It was like a cartoon show that goes on for a half hour and has tons of CGI. Do we need that much CGI? 3. Jim Carrey wasn't in the film. Instead, Jamie Kennedy. Serously? Jamie Kennedy does a horrible job as his character. Along with the rest of the cast. Except for Ben Stein.

These were three reasons why this movie was terrible. Whatever you do, do not watch this movie. I repeat, DO NOT WATCH THIS MOVIE.

I wonder if anything who has seen the movie get the in joke with this dog's name. His name is Otis and while The Mask's dog was Milo (Milo and Otis that movie about a pug dog, Otis and an orange tabby cat, Milo..anyone get it) Anyway, I saw a clip of Otis putting on the mask and as he puts it on, and being the same breed of dog, it is put on the same way...he twirls the same way and he drags it out and places his face and BAM! so the son of the mask does work...Meaning that Otis could be a descendant of Milo and when Jamie Kennedy puts on the mask, he gets a cleft chin, like Jim Carrey's character, and like in the cartoon, the car changes to some whacked out set of wheels.

The mask must have some memory to give Kennedy's character, a butt chin, big teeth and hair, when it was on Dorian, he still had his hair. It also takes the user to clubs apparently

Cannot believe the reviews for this film. My son watched the other day and LOVED IT, laughed out loud and thoroughly enjoyed it. Personally I did not enjoy as much but it wasn't aimed at me!! Get over it, it's a kids movie and any kid will enjoy it!!

review_title: This sequel to The Mask is not good... at all
review_detailed_main:
This film was garbage. It's the sequel to the film The Mask, which is obviously way better than this one. This sequel had terrible jokes, poor acting and too many plot holes!

Tim Avery, an aspiring cartoonist has his life flipped when his dog, Otis, brings home the magic mask of Loki. Loki's infuriated father, Odin, orders Loki to take back what's his, one way or another. The film stars Jamie Kennedy. He did a very poor job playing the role of Tim Avery. In the first film, The Mask, the protagonist was Stanley Ipkiss, played by the hilarious Jim Carrey and with this one, Tim Avery was the protagonist. I don't get that. Why not use Jim Carrey again? He's far better than Jamie. The director, Lawrence Guterman ruined a great movie with this crap follow up! Then there's Tim's wife Tonya, who also did a bad job acting, but hey, she did a better job than Jamie.

This movie is terrible, and no one should have to see it. Well, at least it wasn't as bad as King's Ransom. I watched this movie once or twice, and I will not be watching it again! The best way to enjoy this movie is not to see it in the first place.

review_title: Not up to the original's standards but still pretty amazing
" You can Ip-kiss your ass goodbye".
A Disturbing display of unfunny jokes, hideous aesthetic quality and shocking overall delivery.
review_detailed_main:
I know a lot of people don't like sequels. Some say they endanger the first film by maybe disgracing it, others say they're just a cash in. Sometimes filmmakers get it right (Terminator 2: Judgement Day) but other times, they get it wrong. Son of the Mask is a great example of an instance when they do just that. Son of the Mask has to be one of the worst sequels of all time and even though the first Mask film was no classic, it had its moments and I truly mean that. What Son of the Mask is, is nothing more than a nasty to look at, nasty to watch, mess of bad and unfunny jokes mixed in with horrible music and nasty to look at visuals.

From the off, Son of the Mask begins its terrible decent into celluloid waste. It messes around, very dangerously, with the original Mask film's premise. We are told that Loki: the Nordic God of mischief, created the mask in question and banished it himself to Earth for people to find, fool around with and create mischief of their own. It's Loki's job in this film to find it, by rule of Odin, so that he can get back into Valhalla or wherever. This immediately goes against the first film as we were told Loki was, in fact, BANISHED from his heaven and imprisoned inside this mask that was then placed on the earth; hopefully for no one to ever find. Thus, destroying the equilibrium. This is the first mistake the film makes of many and if you can't even get your equilibriums right, you're in big trouble.

First of all; the characters. Loki in this film is evil. He is genuinely evil and it spoils the image that was created in the first film when he was a mischievous, funny, maybe misunderstood God. In Son of the Mask, he acts as the villain of the piece and that is very disorientating, especially if you've seen the first film and I had a big problem with this. Then we move onto the supposed hero. The hero is Tim Avery (Kennedy) a comic book artist who lacks big inspiration. The fact he has one of the most annoying voices I've ever heard in a film and acts like a twelve year old throughout is enough to utterly repel you from any sort of feeling or relation towards him. These are bad principals for a hero to have. Thirdly, when we actually see our hero wear the mask; its not only a let down as so much as a shockingly unfunny and downright embarrassing series of events that I've ever witnessed in a film.

The scene in question is the company he works for and their large function they're having. There's no build up like their was in the first film, there's no motivation to even wear the mask and our hero's position in Son of the Mask isn't as desperate as Ipkiss' was in the first film. Anyway, once the mask goes on; we're treated to an absolutely hideous display of camera work including close ups of the ugly Mask character's face, fast editing as we struggle to grasp what it is we're seeing, music so bad you have to cover your ears and dance numbers so cringe-worthingly bad that it hurts to watch.

Then comes the plot. The plot is straight forward enough as I've explained. Loki's trying to find his mask that he supposedly created. What happens is Loki spends so much time going from house to house trying to find his Mask that I, personally, began to stop caring. Each visit was just an excuse to 'do something funny' and with jokes so blatantly aimed at children; it was difficult to watch. Another thing is the pointless, 'in there for laughs' subplot that opens up. This involves the baby that's born that is given the powers of the mask. Halfway through the child seems it fit to copy various cartoons on the TV to try and get their father (who's the hero) condemned to a mental institute. This is bad enough as the writers aren't even using their own initiative to create material. To counteract this, the family's dog attempts to defy the baby. Although maybe funny the first time this quickly plays out into utter farce and serves no bearing on the rest of the film; it's just a pointless mess of jokes and gags that makes you feel like you're watching an episode of Road Runner vs. Wile E. Coyote. During this, for some reason the father doesn't actually think of perhaps filming the baby or something like that rather than pick him up and run to the neighbour's house; thus trying to convince them the baby can sing and dance. Oh look, it's stopped: what a surprise.

Plot holes? You bet. Loki has his powers taken away from him and is made mortal during a scrap in an alley way; yet survives the baby's counterattack of having two rubbish skips crush him. He's, literally, just been made mortal yet survives being crushed. Another instance is nearer the end when Avery's Mask character does battle with Loki over the child. Loki states 'Stop! We are evenly matched!' Well, of course you are! The guy's wearing your mask; he has your powers. It took them about ten minutes to figure that out(!) I also really feel that although the acting talent it has on display, if they'd have known it was going to be anything like how it was, they would've kept well away. With these things and a few hundred plot holes heaped on top, Son of the Mask can easily be labelled as one of the worst films ever made; in fact it makes 'The Mask' look like a masterpiece.

review_title: I knew everyone says its awful but i was still surprised by how awful!
review_detailed_main:
Wow!

I have just finished watching Son of the mask and having heard not one good word about it i still didn't expect what i just watched. I thought everyone was being hard on it due to the fact that its another sequel to a Jim Carey movie without Jim Carey (like dumb and dumberer which isn't all bad). This is truly a very bad film, script, direction (i can see a very short career there!) and the acting. Although to give them a break most of the actors do try but the editing and direction just doesn't do anything to assist them. I got this for an 8 year old who saw the trailer with the dog in the mask (they love dogs) and they haven't seen it yet....I'm going to have to take them and buy a flippin dog after showing them this due to the disappointment i can see coming! Awful and truly deserves to be in the 100 worst movies!

Sucky, for lots of reasons including the following. This movie is so stupid, and I thought it was going to be good. Believe me if you want to go spend $20 or more go buy a movie worth watching. This it not it. There are some scenes that have a trace of funniness. But most of them do not. This movie I one that I will put on my "Don't watch again, ever" list. I do not know what to say. It just stunk to "Odin's Throne". And wasn't it a family film? Why do they say "crap" and "D" and "H" and "frick" in it? And it isn't a lot but it isn't a little. About the only good parts are the ones you saw in the commercial. I don't mind but this might be offensive to some.

It's been quite a while since I wrote my original review of 'Son of the Mask,' and I must say, I have matured some. My opinion, however, has not changed. 'Son of the Mask' sucks.

I didn't like the original, and I especially despise this sequel. It's a cheap way for the filmmakers to make a quick buck. I'm not sure I'll ever be able to think of Jamie Kennedy positively again. And poor Alan Cumming. I liked him in 'X2: X-Men United," but here he's an embarrassment.

The only thing the sequel has in common is the cursed Mask in the center of the story. Nothing else. I assure you you'll not see Stanley Ipkiss through the entire film. Sorry.

The movie has a few funny moments; Ben Stein's guest performance seems to be the only positive part of the film. What the filmmakers don't get here is the fact that kids aren't automatically gonna laugh when they see Jamie Kennedy being tossed around by a psychotic, possessed baby. They'll just be disturbed and confused...just like you will be.

Please, please, I beg of you, don't think this movie is 'cute' and buy it. Briskly walk away from that aisle when you see this movie. Watching it is a painful experience.

1.5/4

review_title: I can say one amazing thing about this movie- it was an 80 million dollar prank
review_detailed_main:
This movie isn't very good. The jokes have no originality at all, they're either dull as hell, or taken directly from an old cartoon and poorly executed. The plot is basically just that Tim Avery is a cartoonist with nothing to do with his life. Then the mask just happens to float into Fringe city *Error, the dog from the first movie got the mask, so how did it float somewhere else?* Then Tim gets ahold of the mask and puts it on. When he gets home, he leaves the mask on and conceives a child. Big mistake, the child has the powers of the mask now. Meanwhile, Loki, the owner of the mask is in deep s**t with his father, Odin, because he let the mask fall into mortal hands. Now he has to find a baby and take it too.

The movie isn't very funny, and the special effects are awful, the first movies special effects are 10 years more advanced, pretty bad for a movie made 10 years after. I can credit one thing to this movie, Jamie Kennedy made this movie as an 80 million dollar prank for a special on his show. I don't think anyones ever spent so much money on a prank.

A baby literally bouncing off the walls, a game of "Super Twister," and watching Ben Stein's face separate from his head all mixed into one movie will only bring one thing... the Son of the Mask. Avid cartoonist Tim Avery (Jamie Kennedy, Malibu's Most Wanted, Scream Trilogy) suddenly is burdened to act as a single parent to his newborn son Alvey (Ryan and Liam Falconer) as his wife goes to New York for a week on business. It soon becomes known that Alvey has "powers" of the mask of Loki (Alan Cumming, Romy and Michele's High School Reunion, X2). Now, Loki wants his powers and mask back... Based on the fact that little-known director Lawrence Guterman (Cats & Dogs, Headless!) had directed this film, I definitely did not expect such work. This film was well put together and could attract many audiences. The acting of this motion picture was fulfilling. Kennedy and Cumming portrayed their characters well, which was highly expected from the experience they have. Appearances from Kal Penn (Harold & Kumar Go To White Castle) and Ben Stein (Ferris Bueller's Day Off) really accentuated the film. Transitions throughout the entire hour and 45 minutes were par excellence. Noticing this from a genre of the sort is highly unlikely, considering the director's lack of high profile experience, but it did astonish me. As always, with the good comes the bad. The film contained minor "hokey" elements that I wasn't lured toward. Although I felt this way, the preteens of the theatre obtained kicks and giggles from it. I'll denounce this upon age difference. Son of the Mask is rated PG for action, crude and suggestive humor and language. I must admit it was a little harshly rated. This PG kisses the borderline of PG-13 at times. The raw and risqué humor and language was periodically unnecessary. A nice additive of the movie was the special effects, which were essential. Kennedy spent three and a half hours a day in makeup consisting of foam rubber for the mask. At times, he had to breathe only through a straw. The effects were paid off well as the intrigue struck many viewers. If you are searching for a collective laugh, Son of the Mask may be a film to invest in seeing. Watching the original Mask (Jim Carrey) would not be a prerequisite to see this movie. However, this movie is aimed towards the younger audiences, so mind that. Otherwise, for some good, clean fun, Son of the Mask may be right up your alley.

This movie is a disgrace to the first movie. This movie had nothing to do with Jim Carrey, who was the main star in the first movie. The Mask was such a hilarious movie, but Son of the Mask is sooooooooo awful. I want to give this movie a 0 out of 10 but I can't. I would seriously rate this movie as the Worst Movie of All Time. The animation is poor, and so is the acting. Even Jamie Kennedy is a stupid actor. I don't even know what the executives were thinking of when making this movie. I guess it was the money. That annoys me a lot, when people care about making money more than the quality of the movie. Take Lord of the Rings for example. The people spent millions of dollars into the quality of the movies, and look what came out: one of the best trilogies of all time. Son of the Mask is not a movie, it is a JOKE.

review_title: Jamie Kennedy it a terrible actor

review_title: Overloaded with useless effects and kiddy jokes
review_detailed_main:
Son of the Mask is the sequel to a film that had amazing effects, great "on his own rubbery" actor, Jim Carrey and was dark comedy that made fans look forward to Son of the Mask. Son of the Mask would have been a good movie if it wasn't a sequel, its a Kids Movie, the first was an adults.

The movie went over board with effects that was the trade mark of the first. review_title: How can there be a movie, The Mask, without Jim Carrey ?

review_detailed_main: My god to sit through this horrendous abomination and stay sane is impossible. The this movie is so evil that the devil himself dares not speak of it. Do not watch this movie it or let your kids see it. "A Family Picture" my ass. The CGI is god awful and so out of place that it will make Ride to Hell's sex scenes look natural. The jokes are abysmal. AVOID THIS Movie AT ALL COST.

The Story: Tim Avery (Jamie Kennedey) is a struggling cartoonist who has a run-in with the infamous Mask which leads to him and his wife Tonya (Traylor Howard) having a bouncing baby boy (Ryan and Liam Falconer) who can, in fact, bounce via his inheritance of the Mask's amazing powers. Meanwhile, Loki (Alan Cumming), Norse god of mischief, has been charged by papa Odin (Bob Hoskins) to retrieve the Mask before it can cause any more trouble on Earth.

Wacky hijinks ensue.

The Good: HILARIOUS! There were several several laugh out loud points in this movie. There was the great possibility that this would be one of those movies where the only funny parts were shown in the previews (baby Alvey Avery saying "Mother" in a deep voice still makes me crack up just thinking about it), but such was fortunately not the case here. This movie took the flavor of all the old cartoons I and a few generations before me watched growing up - like the Flintstones and Looney Tunes, both of which are cameoed in the film - and ran headlong with it. Virtually every joke was pulled straight from the cartoon old school, which was just as it should be.

The acting is, for the most part, superb. Cumming does a great job playing the crazified Loki, and Hoskins is a convincing grumpy old man-god (go figure, ha ha). The gem of the film, however, is the main man himself, Jamie Kennedey. His tour as the frizzed out, completely at the end of his rope father is played to the hilt, and it's great fun to watch him gradually go crazy as his son happily drives him there.

With one exception (which I'll elaborate on in a moment), the special effects are also spectacular. The Cats & Dogs crew may not be on the top of the visual effects heap in Hollywood, but for this movie, they don't really have to be. It actually helps that you can tell that the characters are animated when they're doing crazy things, because they're supposed to be doing things that only animated characters can do. If some super-snazzy ILM-like group had come in and made everything up super-realistic, THAT I would have complained about.

The Bad: Now, Mr. Kennedey was great and awesome and wonderful as Tim Avery, but . . . well, as soon as the Mask was slapped onto him, something bad went wrong. It's almost as if the people applying the latex to his face did it incorrectly, and it kept him with almost the exact same facial expression the whole time. It's a big detraction when his face bends and contorts better when he's supposed to be a regular guy than it does when he's supposed to be a cartoon character.

While this is a good movie, I think it's sadly before its time. Son of the Mask really feels less like a direct sequel and more like the end of a trilogy. I believe New Line would have done a good deal better if they'd made a different Mask movie in between this one and the first one.

Finally, there's a short period where Loki loses his powers. I won't go into the details, since I don't wanna be a spoiler, but the duration of this powerlessness is disappointingly short, and not much was really done with it. Which is a shame, since there were several different things that they COULD have done with it . . . ah, well.

The Deal: Overall, I thought this was a very satisfying movie. Sure, it isn't complete brilliance or movie genius or whatever. It isn't going to win any awards or change anyone's life. It's just a series of quick, side-splitting laughs strung together with funny animations. But that's all it really NEEDS to be!

So just sit back, relax, and enjoy the ride, neh?

review_title: Making this movie was a sin
review_detailed_main:
Loki, Norse god of mischief, creates a mask that endows the wearer with cartoon-like powers. At the command of his father, Odin, he spends the rest of the movie looking for the mask so that it can cause no further grief to mankind. In the meantime, the possessor of the mask conceives a child who inherits the powers of the mask. Etc. etc. If this sounds like a pretty thin plot line, it is. Add to this the fact that the movie is handled ineptly from start to finish, and the result is very, very bad. You can find worse movies, but you'll have to actively search for them.

For the most part, Son of the Mask is presented at the intellectual level of a pre-schooler, but in light of scenes such as the mask-baby urinating copiously in six different directions, including on his father, this premise seems unlikely. I asked my son who he thought might have been the target audience for the movie, and he responded "Convicted felons," apparently forgetting for the moment that the Constitution prohibits cruel and unusual punishment.

But just making a bad movie is not a sin, or Hell would be overflowing. What makes it a sin is that $72 million was spent on this piece of garbage. To put things in perspective, the day after we watched Son of the Mask, my son and I watched "Good Night, and Good Luck," a movie that garnered six academy award nominations (including best picture), and was brought in for $7 million. That's right. Just one-tenth of the amount of money spent on Son of the Mask. This, then is the sin -- to flush good money down the sewer, when it could have been better used in making watchable movies, or feeding starving children, or for that matter, almost any other purpose. The producers should truly be ashamed of themselves.

"Son of the Mask" is fast moving, almost funny movie. It has a good cast and a lot of imagination. Maybe it's more weird than funny but it's never boring. It plays like a kids movie with a nice amount of kiddie gross-out humor. I think my daughters would have gotten a kick out of this movie when they were little. "Son of the Mask" is a pretty good movie that deserves a revisit every once in a while.

This has got to be one of the worst movies I've ever seen. If there had existed lower votes then 1 it would have gotten it. OK, it's not as bad as low budget, we-want-to-make-a-really-crappy-movie, movies out there, but considering they had the money to do some special effects they should have used more time on the corny script. The acting is poor and the story starts off confusing, spirals into stupidity and ends up in a bad cliché of a "the most important thing is family" speech. If this is supposed to be a sequel to the original Mask it fails so horribly the it's almost sarcastic. I've just got one option for you: Don't waste your time!!! Watching grass grow is more fun...

review_title: Well, if you ever need a cure for insomnia...
review_detailed_main:
...then this is it. This is forced comedy at it's worst, as for 90 minutes, many things that are not funny happen. There is absolutely no sign of the gag-fest of the original Mask, which rightly put Carrey into mainstream cinema. Jamie Kennedy as main character has no charisma whatsoever and simply looks depressed when he becomes the Mask. Cumming (Loki) just looks a poof throughout.

The ending is nothing that anyone with the IQ of the average 3 year old can figure out. Instead, the real story is the battle between Cumming and Kennedy to bore as many people as possible, both on and off the screen. Carrey grinned like a maniac as the Mask; Kennedy just gimmaces. Just look at the expression on everybody's faces in his vicinity both as Avery and as the Mask. Utter boredom. Cumming has the best part (not that there's much competition - he should have played Avery) but in his opening scene he simply uses his mighty powers of boredom to outwit his foe. His magnum opus for boredom takes place in a busy street in broad daylight where he's flexing his mighty computer-generated powers and is ignored by everyone.

Good bits? Well, I gave this two stars as I think this movie is unique in that most of the budget went on the splendid spangily cheery props and scenery than on the cheap, bland and wooden actors. But despite all the flashy effects, I imagine that anybody watching this dull-fest masquerading as entertainment to the end will be left feeling depressed, thoroughly miserable, heartless, soul-less and sickly-green with nausea. Give them an orange plastic wig to wear and it will be Son of the Mask all over again. Avoid.

Thank goodness I didn't pay any money to see this flick. Let's start off by saying that I had low expectations for this film to begin with. By the time I was 20 minutes into it, I was bored out of my mind. When Tim Avery put on the mask, I thought, hmmm... I wonder what this is gonna be like. It was not in the least bit funny, the humor was terribly dry. Then the animated baby and the dog. Didn't even get a chuckle out of me. I love cartoons, but movies that try to be cartoons better do it amazingly well, which this movie fails to do. The toilet humor was not at all funny either, and I'm a big fan of Terrance and Phillip. The only performance that was acceptable was by Alan Cumming playing Loki. Bob Hoskins as Odin was just laughable. For some reason he feels the need to yell every line, and he does not come across as Godlike. Consider yourself warned, don't watch this!

review_title: We enjoyed this more than the first Mask film
review_detailed_main:
OK maybe not the artistic triumph of all time but it was fun, it was interesting enough to keep us watching all the way through (3 times) and it was a movie that depended on more than one person to make it work.

Alan Cummings was alternately scary and touching and the father character 'Tim' was very believable. The underlying theme of the importance of the bond between fathers and sons was well done without ever getting slushy. The 'gloopy' bits quite honestly compared with some of the gross-out material presented these days on children's cartoon channels was extremely mild and never revolting.

The sets were beautiful, and the CGI was absolutely fine. This film had a good pacey storyline, amusing sympathetic characters and plenty of laugh out loud moments.

I can see why Carrey fans wouldn't like it, but as I am not a Carrey fan and prefer a balanced film with an ensemble of good acting and a share out of amusing lines, rather than a one man ego trip with a back up of lacklustre characters none of whom can steal the star's thunder - I enjoyed this film.

Alan Cummings was a joy and it is nice to watch an actor of his calibre doing what he does best, entertaining and interacting with the other cast members to produce a great film.

I would recommend this to anyone who likes to have a fun time when watching a film and who enjoys surreal wacky stuff.

If you like 'Fairly Odd Parents' 'My Parents are Aliens' 'Tom and Jerry' and 'Coneheads' you will probably enjoy this.

I peek around here from time to time for a good laugh when I know a bad movie is trying to see the light of day. As an adult I've enjoyed reading all the comments for this movie. Now for the confession, I did see a screening of this movie with my children and...THEY seemed to enjoy it. Plot is simple, the colors and animation were just enough to capture their attention. Definitely not something I would recommend to my single friends but other parents shouldn't panic if their 9 year old wants to see this one. Movie goes by pretty quick and you'll laugh at least once. Keep in mind I'm rating it 6/10 in comparison to other kid movies not comedy.

this film does have some redeeming features i suppose you could say that at least it did end and hopefully in a way that there will not be a mask part three.

part one was fun, part two was dreadful please please please don't make a part three.

review_title: Well, it was "free", and I've seen a few worse.
One of the worst films I have ever, EVER had the misfortune of seeing.
review_detailed_main:
The original "Mask" movie made me appreciate Jim Carrey's comedic talents (though I still say he should do some more serious roles- "The Truman Show" blew me away). It had a wild, anarchic, almost over the top style that meant it left an impact- and Carrey was perfect for the film.

Now along comes this stinker.

Let me start by saying this- if you value your life, keep the hell away from this movie. I only just survived, and even then I had to saw off one of my arms. Want more proof as to how stupefyingly horrible this dreck is? It's on the IMDb Bottom 100, and quite honestly one of the worst films I have ever seen.

Plan 9 From Outer Space is widely regarded to be the worst film of all time- and one of the funniest. Why? Because that's how bad it it. The aliens are guys in gorilla suits with fish bowls one their heads. The graves used in the graveyard seen are cardboard, and wobble whenever the wind blows. The aliens use human desks and pens. And the U.F.O.s are hubcaps being dangled around on visible strings. Why do I mention this? It's very simple: in ten years time, Son of the Mask will be considered the Plan 9 of our generation. The already bad effects will look terrible.

The only likable character is, surprisingly, Loki. I didn't mind the actor playing him, but the rest got on my nerves. Who the heck is Jamie Kennedy, anyway/

And who wrote this film? A five year old?

I still have nightmares from this form of child abuse projected onto the big screen. Someone forced me to watch it. I later shot them.

The scariest thing is, there were tons of people involved in making this ****fest.

Avoid.

This is without a doubt, the sorriest excuse of a movie I have ever seen, I mean come on, "Son of the mask"?, what did that have to do with the original, this movie is social garbage and I do not recommend seeing it, don't waste your time or money on it.

This is all the movie is about, mom goes away, leaving dad with the new baby, the dog Otis gets jealous and finds the mask, and thats pretty much it....I was generous and gave this movie a 1/10, but honestly, this movie is pathetic and should never have been submitted...

The original was so much better than this, if it would have had Jim Carrey in it and a complete movie makeover, it might have turned out much better, Jamie Kennedy wasted his time acting in this movie and I feel bad for him cause he had to be set in this horrible movie.....I give this movie a 0/10, but since there is no 0, I generously gave it a 1.

Where is Jim... My sweet Jim Carrey... The mask... SO sad that I couldn't compare this movie with THE MASK. I couldn't say that this movie is the second part of that title that released 10 years ago. This movie is not worth watching. But, if boredom is killing you, you are left with no movies to watch, then you can watch the tom and jerry in this movie. Small kids might like this movie. Kids aged more than 6 might find hard time watching this movie.

The movie ends with the Loki and his father going back to their kingdom... That very scene is awful with the so-called GODs getting upset upon their mistake.

The worst part is... to scare hell out of you, Loki's dad comes out of nowhere; shouts at Loki goes back just to remind the viewer that the movie is still intact and running around the story.

I rate 3!

review_title: Two elements make this movie bad: the script, and Jamie Kennedy's attempt at doing the Mask character.
review_detailed_main:
The script: The script is pretty bad. Dog finds mask...Jamie wears mask to party...Jamie comes back home and knocks up wife...they have a baby. Thus the son of the mask. Baby has ridiculous cartoon-ish powers, while the god LOKI is trying to get the mask back as it was a god creation. So dumb. And if you think Jamie Kennedy doing the Mask was bad, look no further than Bob Hoskins character, Odin. Every time he enters he is yelling...what is up with that? The whole Odin/Loki gods stuff is such a stupid angle.

Jamie Kennedy and the mask: What made the original Mask movie great was Jim Carrey. Not only did Carrey act the Mask better, his "Mask" was dressed much more appropriate. The Mask character was modeled after the Wolf character in Tex Avery's cartoons. Jim Carrey portrayed that character almost perfect, with the clothing, the voice, the actions...everything. Mind I note Jim Carrey's face is much thinner and therefore works better in mimicking the wolf character. Jamie Kennedy has a fat face, is dressed in horrible clothing, wears this UGLY red wig, and worst of all, his voice over on the mask is horrible...not to mention his acting as "Tim Avery". The Mask here is more like...a cartoon version of Mo Collins (from MadTV) doing that character who never finishes her sentences and continues to go higher and higher with her voice. It is horrible. There is little, if any, evidence of the Son of the Mask resembling Tex Avery's creations. Jamie Kennedy's performance, alone, makes this movie very hard to watch.
